tool.name: TreeAnnotator
tool.description: Summarize a sample of trees with annotations

param.name: input
param.label: Input tree file
param.help: File containing a sample of trees (from BEAST MCMC output)

param.label: Node heights
param.help: How to summarize node heights across trees

param.name: burnin_percent
param.label: Burn-in percentage
param.help: Percentage of trees to discard as burn-in

param.label: Posterior probability limit
param.help: Minimum posterior probability for a node to be annotated (optional)

param.label: Target tree
param.help: Optional user-specified target tree to be annotated

param.label: Force discrete traits
param.help: Forces integer traits to be treated as discrete traits

param.name: hpd2d_value
param.label: HPD interval for bivariate traits
param.help: The HPD (Highest Posterior Density) interval to be used

param.label: Not sampled ancestor analysis
param.help: Interpret the tree set as NOT being from a sampled ancestor analysis, even if there are zero branch lengths

tool.help:
**What it does**
TreeAnnotator summarizes a sample of trees from a posterior distribution (those produced by BEAST) into a single annotated tree. It can calculate summary statistics for node heights and other parameters, and annotate the tree with posterior probabilities and other relevant information.
**Input**
The input should be a file containing multiple trees in Trees format typically from an MCMC analysis.
**Options**
- **Node heights**: Method for summarizing node heights across the tree sample
- *Keep*: Retain the heights from a target tree - *Median*: Use median heights across all trees - *Mean*: Use mean heights across all trees - *Common ancestor (CA)*: Use heights from common ancestor nodes
- **Burn-in**: Percentage of initial trees to discard as burn-in period
- **Posterior probability limit**: Only annotate nodes with posterior probability above this threshold
- **Target tree**: Optionally provide a specific tree topology to annotate
- **Force discrete**: Treat integer-valued traits as discrete rather than continuous
- **Bivariate HPD**: Options for calculating highest posterior density intervals for two-dimensional traits
- **Not sampled ancestor**: Use when trees are not from sampled ancestor analysis
**Output**
A single annotated tree file containing summary information from the posterior tree distribution.
